Context:
The text is about a self-assessment for anti-racism practice provided by the college, encouraging individuals to reflect on their current understanding and contributions towards anti-racism. The assessment includes myth busters and a series of questions for self-evaluation. There are five sections in the assessment. Individuals are encouraged to watch one of the listed documentaries and complete a reflection after watching.

The documentaries include "Evan’s Drum" and "Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada". "Evan’s Drum" is described as an uplifting story of cultural pride. The importance of learning about the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada is emphasized, as it is considered the responsibility of settlers, displaced peoples, and migrants to gain an understanding of historical wrongs and ongoing restoration and healing for Indigenous peoples.

There is no specific factual information related to a program offered by the college in this text.

The text encourages individuals to learn about Indigenous lived experiences, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada, and the Call to Action for Truth and Reconciliation. It also mentions resources such as Holy Angels, a short film called "Indigenous Plant Diva" about Cease Wyss, and a documentary called "Healing Journey One Button at a Time." Additionally, there are references to Anishnawbe Health Toronto for counselling services, and hotline numbers 416-415-2000 and TTY: 1-877-515-5559 for additional support. There is no specific information related to programs offered by the college.
